The couple was blessed with five children. Two are already married, while three of them are still attending school, college and in high school. Veronica and her husband are joining their hands in making their business become progressive and part of their initiative is to generate financial support. Thus, Veronica is borrowing loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 8,000 to be able to buy some of their needed furniture equipment. They still need capital to buy wood, the most important material in making furniture. Veronica hopes that lenders will entrust her with the assistance she is seeking.

loans.use: Business Capital.

loans.name: Pout

texts.en:
Pout S. is an older, widowed mother of two children who are married and are still living with her in the family home. One, her daughter, owns a small shop in the market that provides a beauty salon service.

Pout S., 57, makes a living by selling Khmer noodles to her villagers, which earns her an average of $5 profit a day. She will be using this loan to support her daughter’s beauty salon by buying extra hairdressing tools and perfumes for the business.

loans.use: To buy extra hairdressing tools and perfumes for her daughter's beauty salon

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is hoping to obtain additional working capital of PHP 8,000 to have sufficient capital in her vending business. By working hard for them, she wants her family to experience the fullness of life.

Virginia sells snack refreshment such as “halo-halo” which is a mixture of different fruits, milk and crushed ice. She is happy that her husband supports her by utilizing his skills in carpentry in a furniture shop business where he is employed. She hopes that through seeking help for the growth of her business from a microfinance organization, she can provide sufficient needs for her family, especially the educational needs of her youngest child.

Virginia is already 42 years old. She is married to Ronilio S. and is blessed with two children. Their eldest is April who is now married at the age of 23. She did not finish college studies because of her early marriage. The youngest is Josiefat, who is now 18 years old and still studying. Virginia hopes that her youngest child will pursue her studies until she finishes college. Virginia is always willing to do all her best just to provide for all the needs of her children.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Eddie

texts.en: Eddie P. Jr. is a 35-year-old bachelor in Banga, South Cotabato who has been engaged in his farming business for ten years now. He uses a part of his income for his daily needs and he saves some for his future family. And to be more prepared for his married life, he wants to expand his present business, which made him decide to apply for a Php 10,000 loan in the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He chooses to loan at CEVI because of its wide services to people and to have additional finances and savings.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farming necessities

loans.name: Marjohn

texts.en: Marjohn C. is from the town of Damayuhan, Medina, Misamis Oriental. He is 21 years old and is single. Marjohn owns and operates a specialized business, primarily selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Marjohn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the needs of relatives and other family members. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

loans.name: Sheyi

texts.en: Sheyi sells curtain rails and carpet. She is 32 years old and she has three children. She is a LAPO client and hopes for the loan of N100,000 to purchase more curtain rails and carpet to sell. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more curtain rails and carpet to sell

loans.name: Namatovu Margret Group

texts.en: Margaret is the leader of 5 members of a group.  She is 46 years old, married, and has six children between the ages of 22 and 32 years. One of her children goes to school. She resides with five people in a five-roomed house that she owns. Margaret takes care of additional family members.  There is electricity and piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area, in the outskirts of Kampala. Margaret sells second hand clothes, door to door, in Kampala suburbs. She sells to an average of 10 people a day and sells to all categories of people.  She works six days a week. Margaret buys these clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala, and incurs some transport costs. Her major monthly expenses include medication for the family, school fees and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last ten years. Her main challenges include the rainy season, which stops her daily routine of selling door to door. Margaret has been with MCDT for over six years and requesting her twelfth loan, working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothes. Margaret is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise.

loans.use: increase on her inventory to sell.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna S. is the 36-year-old wife of a farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. They are blessed with four children. They started their farming business in the year 1990 with a hectare rice field. This business gives them monthly earnings, enough to support their basic needs. However, Lorna has a plan to venture into a hog-raising project to gain extra income. Presently, her focus is on the sustainability of their present venture. The business is in need of additional capital to purchase some farming necessities. This is her main purpose of applying for a PHP 10,000 loan at the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). 

As a mother and wife, Lorna strives hard to support her husband to realize their family plans. Aside from praying for good health, the couple is helping each other to reach a better quality of life for their family. She finds availing loans from CEVI’s and its wide services to people as a big help to reach their dreams earlier than expected.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farming necessities.

loans.name: Rey

texts.en: Rey R., 42, is a villager living in the Province of Siem Reap, working in construction. He is married with two kids who are enrolled in primary school, while his wife works selling sweets for pupils in the local public school. Rey R. will be using a loan to add to his saving to buy an old motor for riding to work and for his family’s traveling needs.

loans.use: To buy an old motor for riding to work

loans.name: Jane's Group

texts.en: T. Jane is a hard working and bold lady who knows what she wants, no matter what. She is the leader of Kanyansheko Bakyara Twimukye group in Ibanda and a widow, with 7 children. All of her children are in O level school. She also cares for many relatives, although they do not stay with her. Jane has had a business of rearing goats for sale for 3 years, in Nyakigando village. The main business challenge is the failure to access drugs for her animals. She is able to make 50,000 UGX as profits per week, hence being able to look after her children. Jane is also a farmer, though on a small scale, and the food helps to feed her children and the excess is sold off for money. She has a dream of buying more goats and of growing more crops so as to turn into a modern farmer for more profits from more customers. She needs a loan to be able to buy more goats for her farm.

loans.use: Buying more goats for her farm.

loans.name: Nakawuka Epharance Group

texts.en: Ephrance is the leader of a 4 member group.  She is a 34-year-old single mother of three children, aged between 11 and 15 years. All of her children go to school. She resides in a rented one-roomed house where she is staying with four people. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets three meals a day. She resides and works in a semi-urban area, which is in the outskirts of Kampala. Ephrance sells vegetables in Bwaise Market, one of Kampala suburbs. She sells to all categories of people, an average of 10 customers a day. She works six days a week. Ephrance buys the vegetables from Nakasero Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala, and uses public transport to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last ten years. Her main challenge is the rainy season, which stops her daily routine of moving door to door. Margaret has been with MCDT for over ten years and requesting her twentieth loan, working all this long with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more fruit and vegetables. Ephrance aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory.

loans.name: Marie Josée

texts.en: Marie Josée N. has requested a 500,000 Rwandan franc (FRW) loan from Vision Finance Company to expand her tailoring business. At just 22 years old, she is married and has run her business for six years! She employs two other people at her Kigali-based business and currently earns about 160,000 FRW per month. With this loan she would like to buy more fabric and another sewing machine. These additions will help Marie Josée to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and a new sewing machine.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn is married to Michael and they live in the rural community of Lamo, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. They have a child named Ryzen Carl. Through their barber-shop business, the young couple is able to support their daily needs. However, due to lack of capital, the couple cannot compete with other barber-shops in their village. For this, Jocelyn seeks the financial support of Kiva lenders.  She is requesting to borrow around PHP10, 000 as additional capital so that they will able to develop their barber-shop and to encourage more customers. Jocelyn is also planning to venture into a direct selling business while at the same time helping her husband in managing their barber-shop business.

loans.use: Business Capital.

loans.name: Oluwakemi

texts.en: Oluwakemi sells foodstuffs and drinks. Oluwakemi is 31 years old and she is married, with a child. Oluwakemi lives in Lagos state, Nigeria. She hopes for a loan in the amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She is grateful to all kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli P. is from the village of Damayuhan, Gingoog City. She is 50 years old. Arceli is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Arceli owns & operates a business buying & selling green bananas and coconut fruit. Her husband is a fisherman. Arceli is supporting this business to expand. Arceli and her husband have been engaged in these businesses for over 20 years and earn approximately 15,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Arceli joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. Arceli has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase a motor for their pump boat. Arceli is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP to be used to purchase additional fishing nets and to finance her buying and selling business. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Arceli from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and to finance her buying and selling business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine lives in the rural community of Lamo in Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya, together with her husband and two children: George and Lynette Joy. The children are both studying in high school level.  

Josephine patiently maintains her canteen to further support the education of her children. She would like to borrow a loan amounting to PHP 5,000 as additional capital to increase her income. She will utilize the loan to purchase more inventory.  She plans to expand her eatery into a general store business.  She is hoping that lenders will assist her in fulfilling her business endeavor.

loans.use: Business Capital.

loans.name: Jean Baptiste

texts.en: At just 19 years old, Jean Baptiste H. from Kigali, Rwanda has run a tailoring business for 3 years and employs 2 people! He works about 12 hours per day to generate a monthly profit of 130,000 Rwandan francs (FRW). He has just requested his first loan (of 500,000 FRW) from Vision Finance Company to expand his business.

loans.use: Business expansion.

loans.name: Deus' Group

texts.en:
M. Deus is a determined and hardworking man who is married with seven children, all in primary schools.

Deus has had a business selling produce from Rugaaga III centre for four years and his biggest business challenge is the poor seasons but, through experience, he has learnt to deal with them. He is able to make UGX 150,000 as monthly profits and he hopes to expand his business further as well as to have a healthy, good family.

Deus needs a loan to be able to buy more produce for his business in order to avoid shortages for his customers. Deus is the leader of Rugaaga I Tutungukye group in Ibanda.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Nabyonga Edith Group

texts.en:
Edith is the leader of a five member group. She is a 35 year old, married with six children; ages four to 22. Three of her children go to school.

She owns a one room house where she stays with eight people. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. Her family gets two meals a day. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala.

Edith sells bananas in the Makerere Kikoni Market, one of Kampala suburbs. She sells to an average of seven people a day and works six days a week. Edith buys bananas from the Nakasero Market, one of the busiest in Kampala. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family.

She has been in this business for the last twenty years. Edith has been with MCDT for over eight months and is servicing her second loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more bananas. Edith hopes her business will grow bigger and to own a permanent business premise. .

loans.use: Buy bananas to resell.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita C. is a widow. She lives with her three children at Barangay Lamo in Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. With her desire to give her children a better future, she sacrifices her time to earn a living to send them to school. She is thankful because her children help her earn income on weekends and vacation days. She manages a direct selling business. She is a dealer of AVON products in her village.

Julita also sells native cakes in the market and sometimes roams around the village to sell her products. She earns PHP1,000 and she used her income for the school allowance of her children. Julita decided to borrow a loan of PHP10, 000 for her direct selling and vending businesses, to increase her daily income.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en: Margarita operates a general store in Lamo Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya.  She is happily married to Bernard V. but unfortunately, they have not been blessed with their own child.  That’s why they decided to adopt Sherwin, who is 18 years old.  He is in high school.  Margarita hopes for the best for Sherwin and treats him as her own child.  Margarita requests a loan of PHP10, 000 from KIVA lenders to develop her store.  Margarita says “success could be more fulfilling if she makes the best out of life's difficulties.”

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Epiphanie

texts.en: Epiphanie N. is 36 years old and a married mother of three children, ages 1, 4, and 7.  Epiphanie runs a small boutique in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, where she sells raw agricultural products.  Her business employs two other people and Epiphanie currently earns 160,000 Rwandan francs (FRW) per month.  In order to expand her product offerings, she has decided to seek credit for the first time.  A 500,000 FRW loan will allow her to purchase rice, five sacs of beans, and three sacs of sugar to add to her product offerings.

loans.use: Buy items to resell.

loans.name: Marjorie

texts.en:
Due to the economic crisis, life has become difficult for the family of Marjorie LaT.. Marjorie is married to Henry and they live in Barangay Lamo in Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. The couple aims to improve their status of living and to give their children a better future. They finished college courses but unfortunately did not find good jobs.

Her husband chose to work abroad while Marjorie manages a hog raising business to care for their family. Aside from maintaining her hog raising, Marjorie sometimes sells vegetables and snacks in their village. At present, she seeks a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP5,000 to make her business grow.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Rene Boy

texts.en: Rene Boy P. is from the village of GK, Santiago, Iligan City. He is 23 years old, is separated from his spouse, and has one infant child. Rene Boy owns and operates a specialized business, primarily buying and selling scrap materials in his village. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Rene Boy joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be his first from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of his family. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his business

location.town: GK, Santiago, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody belongs to a poor family in their village. She always aims to become successful in life in order to give her child and future children a better and comfortable living condition. In this regard, she encouraged her husband Domingo to earn and save for the future of their family through venturing into a direct-selling business. Therefore, she is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders of PHP 10,000 as additional working capital for the said business. Her husband also works as a welder in Subic

They both sacrifice for the future welfare of their children. According to her, she is able to gain a net income of PHP 2,500 monthly which she uses to support their daily needs and to pay some monthly bills and expenses. Through the loan, Melody is hoping that she will be able to help her husband to uplift their living condition into a progressive one someday.

loans.use: To use as business capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Myra

texts.en:
Myra M. is a resident of Barangay Lamo Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. She is a simple mother of three and a loving wife to Ligion M.. Her children are presently studying in high school and in elementary grades. Despite the hardships of life, the couple remains strong and perseveres for the progress of life.

Her husband drives a passenger jeepney while Myra manages a hog-raising business. Because of lack of financial capital to sustain her business, Myra was encouraged to borrow PHP10,000 from Kiva as financial assistance with her hog-raising business. She will buy stock of hog-growing feed and, somehow, an additional piglet to further grow her business. She realizes that the livestock business is also a good livelihood to help cope with the difficulties of life.

loans.use: To purchase hog-growing feed

loans.name: Margaret  Nakanjanko Group

texts.en:
Margaret is the leader of a five-member group. She is 37 and married with four children between the ages of 2 and 12. Three of her children go to school. She rents a two-room house where she is staying with six people. Margaret  takes care of additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day.

She resides and works in a semi-urban area in the outskirts of Kampala. Margaret sells fried food in the Kasubi Market in one of Kampala's suburbs. She sells to an average of 50 people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. Margaret buys raw materials from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala, and uses public transport to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last nine years.

Besides frying eatables, she operates a ladies salon, also in Kasubi. Her main challenge is the rainy season, which disrupts her as she works from an open place. Margaret has been with MCDT for more than eight months and is servicing her second loan, working with the same group mates. She wants to use this loan to buy more cooking oil and wheat flour. Margaret aspires to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent premise for her business.
.

loans.use: Increase her stock of cooking oil and wheat flour

loans.name: Nelia

texts.en:
Nelia manages a small hog-raising business that serves as her source of income. She wants to improve her business in order to earn more profit. Thus, she is borrowing a loan from Kiva lenders in the amount of PHP10,000 to support her hog-raising business. This business is a big help in supporting the education of her children, who are still studying. Her husband, Johnny James, also works hard to overcome the difficulties of life. The couple and their children live in the rural village of Lamo Dupax del Norte in the Nueva Vizcaya province. 

Aside from hog raising, the couple also buys and sells processed food like tocino, a sweet pork breakfast dish, and longanisa, a sweet sausage. The couple really works very hard for the welfare of their family and to sustain their daily needs. They don't take things for granted and do what they can do every day without complaining. Nelia always bears in mind her motto in life, “If there is a will, there is always a way."

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Kindé Yvette

texts.fr:
A. Kindé Yvette est née vers les années 1967 à OUIDAH, l’une des villes historiques et touristiques du Bénin. Kindé Yvette est mariée et est mère de deux enfants. Mais Kindé Yvette est veuve depuis 2006. Depuis  2003 Kindé Yvette réside AKPAKPA  un quartier populaire de la ville de  Cotonou,  Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin et elle y mène son activité. Kindé Yvette est dans le secteur de la restauration. C’est Kindé Yvette elle-même qui gère son restaurant. 

Grâce aux revenus de son activité de restauration,  Kindé Yvette arrive à  subvenir à ses besoins. Kindé Yvette a déjà bénéficié de plusieurs crédits de ALIDé; crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener ses activités à un stade supérieur. Kindé Yvette veut  mieux développer les activités de son restaurant  en vue d’une meilleure prestation envers sa clientèle dont le nombre ne cesse de croitre. C’est pourquoi Kindé Yvette sollicite un crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Kindé Yvette was born around 1967 in OUIDAH, one of the historic and touristic cities of Benin. She is married and the mother of two, but she has been a widow since 2006. Since 2003, Kindé Yvette has been living in AKPAKPA, a working-class district of the city of Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin, where she operates her business. She is in the restaurant business. She herself manages the restaurant. Thanks to the revenues from this business, Kindé Yvette manages to support herself. She has already benefited from several loans with Alidé and has repaid them. She was able to use the loans to raise her business to a higher level. She wants to improve her restaurant business with the aim of providing improved offerings and services to her customers, who are ever-growing in number. This is why she is requesting a fifth loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 50-kg sacks of rice, three 500-mg boxes of macaroni, 25 kilos of beans, two 100-kg sacks of corn, and a 25-L drum of peanut oil

loans.name: Um

texts.en: Um S. is 30-year-old grocery seller--selling cooking ingredients, sweets, and candies for kids in her village. She currently earns around $2 a day. Her husband works to cover the family’s expenses by cultivating rice. This couple lives with one lovely kid in the rural area of Pursat Province. Um S. requests a loan to purchase more grocery items to sell. This will provide her with extra income.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items to sell

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raquel A. is 39 years old. She was able to graduate from college but, due to a lack of job opportunities, she ended up being a school canteen operator.

Raquel sells foods at very affordable prices for student meals which helps her husband Rodolfo A. in sustaining their daily living. She is thankful that her husband is employed as a teacher but, because of their growing needs, the couple needs to work very hard.

Raquel is requesting the amount of PHP 10,000 for further improvement of her food-vending business so that she will be able to increase her family’s daily income.

loans.use: To use as business capital

location.town: Lamo Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda and Ernesto M. are a couple who help each other in struggling through life’s difficulties. They make farming and vending as their sources of income. They live in the village of Lamo, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya. The highest education they attained is only high school because of early marriage. At present, they have four children and do all their best to support their children’s studies in order for them to have better living opportunities someday.

Rhoda is requesting the amount of PHP 10,000 for her vending business. She also wants to put up a sari-sari store (a typical village store) in their village to increase her family’s daily income. She sacrifices to roam every house in their village just to sell vegetables and other vending products she is able to sell. Rhoda believes that with their patience and hard work, they can surpass the hardships of life, of course with the help of Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To use as business capital

location.town: Lamo, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Viriginie

texts.en: Virginie M. has run a restaurant in Kigali, Rwanda, for six years and now she has decided to take out her first loan to expand her business. She is 34 years old, married, and has four children. She employs two other people at her restaurant, but she still must put in long hours (7 a.m. till 8 p.m.) to keep it running. This 500,000 Rwandan franc (FRW) loan will help her to expand her restaurant.

loans.use: To help her to expand her restaurant

loans.name: Mary Serungoji Group

texts.en:
Mary is the leader of 5 members of a group. She is a 31 years old and married with one child aged 12 years. Her child goes to school. She resides and owns a three-roomed house where she is living with six people. She takes care of four additional family members There is electricity and piped water at her home and the family gets two meals a day.

Mary resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a shop selling clothing materials in Kiyembe, one of the Kampala suburbs. She sells to an average of five people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works six days a week and uses public transport to work. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees, feeding the family and rent for the business premises.

Mary has been in this business for the last fifteen years. Her main challenge is license fees. She has been with MCDT for over twelve years and is servicing her twentieth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials to sell. She is aspiring to seeing her business grow bigger and owning another shop.

loans.use: To buy more sewing materials

loans.name: Ngen

texts.en:
Ngen S., 50, is married with three children and lives in Kampong Cham province. She is a farmer and also sells rice, making around $7 each day. Her husband stays at home and sometime helps his wife selling the rice in the market.

Ngen S. is asking for a loan of $500 to expand her rice stock. She believes that this loan can raise her standard of living and provide valuable resources for her family.

loans.use: To expand her rice stock

loans.name: Yaotcha

texts.fr:
H. Yaotcha est agée de 35 ans et née à Cotonou, Capitale Economique  de la République du Bénin. Yaotcha est mariée à KPEYITO Assogba, un maçon de profession. Yaotcha est mère de cinq (5) enfants : deux de ces enfants vont à l’école et les trois autres aident leur mère dans ses activités. Yaotcha réside avec sa famille à Hlacomè, un quartier très peuplé de la ville de Cotonou. 

C’est depuis 5 ans que Yaotcha est la restauration. Yaotcha vend aussi des divers (Bonbons, biscuits, boîtes de lait, de sardines, de tomates, de sucres, les pâtes alimentaires, les savons de lessive, de vaisselle et de toilette, piles, bougies, etc.). Pour ses achats, s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, grand marché international du Bénin. 

Yaotcha a déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits de ALIDé; crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés et avec lesquels elle a pu amener ses activités à un stade supérieur. Yaotcha veut  mieux développer les activités de son restaurant  en vue d’une meilleure prestation envers sa clientèle dont le nombre ne cesse de croitre. C’est pourquoi Yaotcha sollicite un cinquième crédit de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Yaotcha is 35 years old and was born in Cotonou, the economic capital of the Republic of Benin. She is married to KPEYITO Assogba, a mason by profession, and is the mother of five children: two of them go to school, and the other three help their mother with her work. Yaotcha resides with her family in Hlacomè, a highly-populated district of the city of Cotonou. For five years, Yaotcha has been in the restaurant business. She also sells various goods: candies, cookies, canned foods (milk, sardine, tomatoes), sugar, pasta, soaps for the laundry, dishes, and bath, charcoal, phone recharge cards, etc. As for her purchases, she stocks up at Dantokpa, the grand international marketplace of Benin. Yaotcha has already benefited from four loans with Alidé, and she has repaid them. She was able to use them to raise her business to a higher level. She wants to improve her restaurant business with the aim of providing a better offering to her customers, who are ever-growing in number. This is why she is requesting a fifth loan from Alidé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy two 50-kg sacks of rice, a 500-mg box of macaroni, 25 kilos of beans, a 100-kg sack of corn, and a 25-L drum of oil

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong A., 39, is a farmer living in Kampong Cham province with her husband and four of her children. She and her husband typically make a combined $7 in revenue each day.

The climate conditions have been unfavorable for farming in Cambodia this past year and this has caused food prices to soar. Inflation has also been out of control, as this has turned into a difficult economic year for many Cambodians, Kong A. included. In light of these economic difficulties, she is asking for a loan of $1,000 to purchase fertilizer and a water pump to irrigate her farm. She sees this business opportunity as a way to increase her income and to provide a higher standard of living for her and her family.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and a water pump

loans.name: Jun

texts.en: Jun S., 39, is a farmer in the Batambong Province which is so famous for producing good rice in Cambodia. Her husband is a farmer too; however, he is also a builder because his income is a bit low. The only hope to supply a good standard of living is to make use of their farmland to produce more rice and sell it for more income. So S. has made up her mind to take a loan of $1,000 to purchase more farmland. (S.'s husband is presented in the picture with his mechanical plow because S. is not available)

loans.use: To buy more farmland

loans.name: Celerina

texts.en:
Celerina A., 52 years old, is the mother of three. Her husband is a farmer and their family has been engaged in farming for twenty-five years now. Their expertise in this field gave them the confidence to start a small business of farm financing. They are optimistic that this venture will elevate their standard of living and will eventually realize their dreams for their children to pursue and finish their studies. 

In order to sustain their business, Celerina has been searching for a micro-finance institution that will lend her enough funds as additional capital. When she heard about the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) and its services, she immediately inquired for a loan application. Presently, she is applying for a loan of Php 10,000.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farm necessities

loans.name: Damian

texts.en:
Farming has supported Damian C., 43 years old, and his family for the last twenty years. He is happily married to a housekeeper and is the father of three.

Although his business is earning enough, he finds the need to expand it due to the growing needs of his family. His children are schooling and, as parents, he and his wife really want to send them to college and have them obtain a degree. So he is saving more for the greater demand of their education.

Damian is currently applying for a Php 10,000 loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He finds it advantageous to loan at CEVI because, aside from meeting his need for additional capital, he also learns other business techniques because CEVI holds training and seminars about business management for its active members.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farming necessities

loans.name: Agnes Nakazi Group

texts.en:
Agnes is the leader of four members of a group. She is a 28 years old and married with one child aged 1 year. She resides in and rents a one-roomed house where she is living with three people. Agnes doesn’t take care of any additional family members There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day.

Agnes resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She owns a retail shop in Makerere, one of Kampala’s suburbs, selling home products materials. She sells to an average of fifteen people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week. She uses public transport to and from shopping in Kampala City shops. Her major monthly expenses include medication, rent for both her home and business and feeding the family.

Agnes has been in this business for the last two years. Her main challenge is transportation of her products from town to her premises and license fees. She has been with MCDT for over eight months and is servicing her second loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil for her shop. Agnes is aspiring to see her business grow bigger and to own another wholesale shop.

loans.use: To increase on her stock

loans.name: Ma

texts.en: Ma N., 42, is married with four children and lives in Kampong Cham province. She typically makes $10 every day selling porridge and cooked rice. She is also supported by her husband who is a mechanic. Ma N. is asking for a loan of $700 to purchase mechanic’s tools for her husband.

loans.use: To purchase mechanic's tools for her husband

loans.name: Eab

texts.en:
Eab O., 29, has been involved in the business of selling sugar-palm juice in her village in Batambong Province since 2006. She earns gross revenue of $18 per day. She lives with her husband and three children who are still very young, and have not attended school yet. Her husband has no business, but he always helps his wife with the business described above.

O. plans to take a loan of $1,000 to buy a new machine to squeeze sugarcane in order to extract the juice easily and fast.

loans.use: To buy a new machine to squeeze sugarcane

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Em N., 53, is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province. All of the children are married and no longer live at home.

To earn a living she grows and sells vegetables in the market. On average, she is able to make about $10 in revenue per day. Her husband has been a moto-taxi driver for ten years and normally he makes $5 each day. Em N. would like to take out a loan of $800 to replace her husband’s old and unreliable motorbike as the old one uses a lot of gas and has had to be fixed many times.

loans.use: To replace her husband's old and unreliable motorbike

loans.name: Anastasie

texts.en: Anastasie M. has requested a 500,000 Rwandan franc (FRW) loan to help her expand her business. She is 42 years old, and the married mother of three children. She sells non-alcoholic beverages in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda, and has been in the business for four years. She currently makes a monthly profit of 200,000 FRW. This is her first loan, with which she hopes to expand her product offering.

loans.use: To expand her product offering

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio V. is a 59-year-old native of Banga, South Cotabato. He is happily married to Enriqueta V. with whom he is blessed with three children. He provides for them through his farming business. 

His venture in farming began with a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field and a starting capital of Php 10,000. Now, Antonio plans to expand this by borrowing Php 10,000 from the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He is satisfied with the variety of services CEVI is offering but, most of all, he enjoys the interaction between members. He appreciates every group meeting wherein he gets to share his views and reflections about life to others and, in return, he learns from them too.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farming necessities

loans.name: Daisy Nabukalu Group

texts.en:
Daisy is the leader of four members of a group. She is 56 years old and married with five children aged between 20 and 35. Two of her children go to school. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house where she is living with three people. She takes care of five additional family members. There is electricity but no piped water at her home. The family gets two meals a day.

Daisy resides and works in a semi-urban area which is in the outskirts of Kampala. She operates a retail shop in Kanyanaya, one of Kampala’s suburbs. She sells to an average of forty people a day and sells to all categories of people. She works seven days a week.

Daisy buys home product items from Kikuubo, one of the busiest places in Kampala, and uses public transportation to and from shopping. Her major monthly expenses include medication, school fees and feeding the family. She has been in this business for the last nine years. Her main challenge is the ever-rising price of commodities which affects her customers because she can’t easily increase the prices at which she sells her commodities.

Daisy has been with MCDT for over six years and is servicing her eighth loan, working with the same group members. She wants to use this loan to buy more commodities like sugar, soap, cooking oil, salt and wheat flour. Daisy hopes to see her business grow bigger and to own a permanent business premises.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Kheoun

texts.en: Kheoun S., 56, has been involved in her tailoring business in Batambong province since 2006, with an income of $2.50 per day. Together, she and her husband have three children: one of them is a student and the rest are employed as construction workers. S. plans to take a loan $350 to buy fabric for tailoring and designing into clothes for customers. She hopes she will be able to generate more income for the family’s use and to pay expenses.

loans.use: To buy fabric to make clothes for customers

loans.name: Biema

texts.en:
Having been engaged in farming with her husband for fifteen years, 35-year-old Biema Y. pursued a farm production business to provide for their basic needs and their only child’s education. She plans to own a hectare (2.5 acres) of rice field in the future, which makes her become more determined to expand their business.

Currently, Biema is applying for a Php 10,000 loan from the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) to raise additional capital for their business. She also wants to obtain CEVI’s other services like micro-insurance and training.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and other farming necessities

loans.name: Pech

texts.en: Pech A., 35, has sold vegetables and pork in the local market for years. She is a married mother blessed with four children who attend school.  Her husband is a domestic animal trader.  He buys mature pigs and oxen, slaughters them, and sells the meat to market sellers.  Pech is applying for a $1000 loan to buy a used-car so her husband can transport more meat.  With the remainder of the loan she will buy more mature pigs for slaughtering to sell.

loans.use: Buy a used-car.

loans.name: Abosede

texts.en: Abosede is a fashion designer and she also sells clothes, sarongs, and tailoring materials. Abosede is asking for a loan of N50,000 to purchase more clothes and sarongs to sell. She is 42 years old, married, and has six children. She says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Sim R. is 38 years old and resides in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband are vegetables wholesalers. Every morning, she and her husband go to the province market to buy vegetables and then bring them to sell in the local market. On average, they make around USD $15 in revenue each day. This couple has four children, three of whom are in school and one helps her to sell vegetables. Sim R. would like a loan of USD $600 to purchase more vegetables to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie C., 47 years old, started her business 20 years ago. She always wanted to assist her husband in farming to earn enough to be able to send their seven children to school and to meet their daily needs. She plans to acquire another hectare to expand the business. But in the meantime, her main concern is to sustain her business. In order to this, she’ll need additional capital to purchase fertilizer and other farming necessities.

Thus, she applies for a Php 10,000.00 loan from the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). Since CEVI offers wide services aside from the loans they, Rosemarie is confident that she can meet her obligation responsibly and their ambition to have a better life is now just a few steps away.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and other necessities

loans.name: Norng

texts.en: Norng S., 37, lives with her three children and her husband in the Kampong Cham province. She sells roasted beef in her area and typically makes US $6. She is also supported by her husband who operates a moto-taxi business. Norng S. is asking for a loan of US$1000 to buy beef and to repair her leaking roof.

loans.use: To buy beef and repair leaking roof.

loans.name: Francois

texts.en: François K. has run a clothing shop business for the past eight years and he is requesting a loan of 500,000 Rwandan francs (FRW) to expand it. François a 52-year-old married man with seven kids ranging from age 5 to 19. He earns 300,000 FRW per month, but would like to grow his business. This is François’s first loan with Vision Finance Company. He will use the loan to purchase some new clothes for his shop.

loans.use: New inventory for the shop

loans.name: Sgeam

texts.en: Sgeam S., 30, has been involved in a business of producing traditional tools to make an offering to spirits (this tool is commonly used by Cambodian people for asking the spirit to bring peace and happiness for their family). Together S. and her husband have four children attending a local school. Her husband has been involved in a business similar to S.'s, too, so S. plans to take a loan of US$ 700 to buy raw materials to produce the tools.

loans.use: Buying raw materials to produce her "tools"

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta O. is from the village of Danao. She is 49 years old. Julieta is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a manufacturing business making necklaces. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from manufacturing these necklaces and selling them to local businesses and community members. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 40,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 8th loan taken out by Julieta from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Seth

texts.en: Seth S. is 29 years old and lives with her husband and her young child in Kampong Cham province. She is a good housewife who stays at home looking after the child and cooking for the family. Her husband who pictured here is a local construction foreman and typically makes US$ 10 every day. Seth needs a loan to purchase more construction tools for her husband so that he can construct big building.

loans.use: To purchase contruction tools for her husband

loans.name: Primitive

texts.en: Primitive M. is a 46-year-old widow with four children, aged 13, 15, 17, and 20. For the last four years, Primitive has run a liquor (beverage) business. She currently brings in 300,000 Rwandan francs (FRW) in monthly profits to support herself and her family.  She has requested a loan of 500,000 FRW to buy 30 cases of beer.

loans.use: buying 30 cases of beer

loans.name: Marn

texts.en:
Marn S., 39, is involved in a business of selling fish at a local market in Battambong Province, and her income is US$ 5 per day. Together she and her husband have three school-aged children. Her husband is unemployed, yet he always helps S. in the business because it is hard work.

S. plans to take a loan of US$ 1000 to expand her inventory of fish to sell for more income since she has repeat customers who are always come to buy her fish. (Her husband is present in the picture with his motorbike used for transporting fish to sell.)

loans.use: buying more fish to sell

loans.name: Beng

texts.en:
Beng L., 53, and her husband, Mr. Yang Torng (shown in the picture), 54, live with their four children in the Province of Pursat. Beng and Yang are local farmers, growing rice, vegetables and fruit in the village. Their children are students and they also work on the farm when they are free from studying.

To make plowing the farmland during this coming growing-crop season easier, Beng L. would like a loan to buy a water buffalo. In the future, she can raise its offspring and make plowing even easier.

loans.use: To buy a water buffalo

loans.name: Ramonita

texts.en:
Ramonita E. is from the village of Danao. She is 67 years old. Ramonita is widowed and has adult children. To make a living, Ramonita owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Ramonita has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2000, Ramonita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ramonita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional fish to sell.

Ramonita is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Ramonita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Sear

texts.en:
Sear K., 47, is a widow who lives with her two children in Kampong Cham province. She sells fermented fish and vegetables in the market, making around US$ 2 each day and is supported by one of the children who is a garment factory worker.

Food prices have soared in the past year as inflation has gotten out of control in Cambodia. Unfavorable climate conditions have also played a factor in making the price of rice very high. Sear K. is asking for a loan of US$ 700 to purchase fermented fish and vegetables to sell. She is confident that this will be a good business venture and sees it as a tool to increase her income and raise her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase fermented fish and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Ngea

texts.en: Ngea R., 45, is a grocery seller at a local market in Battambong Province with an income of US$ 3 per day. Together R. and her husband have three children: two of them are students and the oldest child is employed as a builder. Due to the difficulties of family expenses and living,  Ngea R. wants to take out a loan of US$ 1000 to expand the inventory of her grocery store. (Her husband is present in the picture because R. was not available.)

loans.use: buying groceries

loans.name: Annonciata

texts.en: Annonciata M. runs a hardware store in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. She is 42 and has one 8-year-old child still at home, with the other three no longer dependents. As Annonciata is a widow, she is the only source of income for her family with monthly profits of 200,000 Rwandan francs (FRW). She has run her business for five years and employs one other person. She is requesting her first loan to grow her business. Annoniciata’s loan request is 500,000 FRW.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida C. is from the village of Danao. She is 33 years old. Aida is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Aida owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2003, Aida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. Aida is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 13th loan taken out by Aida from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Khim C., 42, is married and lives with her husband and three of her children in the Kampong Cham province. She sells sugar cane juice and also works in a grocery store, making about $9 in revenue every day, while her husband is a mechanic who makes $5 per day. Three of their children are in school. 

To earn more money, Khim C. would like to take out a loan of $600 to expand her grocery’s inventory to meet her clients' demand. She sees this as a profitable venture that will not only increase her income, but also raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To expand her grocery’s inventory

loans.name: Verginia

texts.en:
Verginia L. is from the village of Danao. She is 46 years old. Verginia is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Verginia owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Verginia is just starting this business.

In 2006, Verginia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Verginia is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Verginia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Heng C., 21, is married and lives in Kampong Cham province with her two young children. She sells resin and daily makes around US$ 3. Her husband is a moto-taxi driver who also makes around US$ 4 each day. The rise of rice prices in Cambodia has made business difficult for Heng C. and she is asking for a loan of US$ 1000. With the loan, she would like to replace their old and unreliable motorbike for her husband as the old one is uses a lot of gas and has had to be fixed many times.

loans.use: To replace an old and unreliable motorbike

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel M. is a single entrepreneur of 27. He runs a clothing shop in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. He has had the shop for about 6 years and he currently employs two others. His clothing retail business allows him to make 220,000 Rwandan francs (FRW) per month in profits. To expand his business, Emmanuel has requested a 500,000 FRW loan from Vision Finance Company to purchase more clothing to add to the shelves.

loans.use: New inventory

loans.name: Lek

texts.en: Lek S., 32, is married and lives with her two young children in Kampong Cham province. She is a good housewife who stays at home looking after the children and cooking for the family. Her husband sells bananas and makes US$ 3.50 each day. Lek S. is asking for a loan to purchase bananas for her husband to sell at the market.

loans.use: Selling bananas at the market

loans.name: Eleonor

texts.en:
Eleonor J. is from the village of Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 48 years old. Eleonor is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Eleonor owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling various delicacies and viands within the Cagayan de Oro airport. Eleonor has been engaged in her business for over 27 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Eleonor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eleonor has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in renovating the business.

Eleonor is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 7th loan taken out by Eleonor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to finance the education of her children and supplement the income of the family.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Meth

texts.en: Meth S., 25, is married and works together with her husband, Rem Than, in Kampong Cham province. They sell beef in the local market and that generates about US$ 10 every day. They work very hard in the market and need to purchase more beef to meet their customers' demand. Meth S. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase beef to sell.

loans.use: Selling beef in the market

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel C. is from the village of Danao. She is 52 years old. Isabel is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Isabel owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Isabel has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2005, Isabel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Isabel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. Isabel is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Isabel from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sha Gull Group

texts.en: Sha Gull is the group leader of Sha Gull group. There are four members in this group. All of them would like to receive money for their businesses. Three requested a loan of 30000 Afghanis. Sha Gull and Tallwasha want to take a loan for their business of beading. Haydaytalah wants to take a loan for his general store to enlarge his shop.  Khasraw wants to take a loan for his bookstore. He wants to buy necessary materials for his business. With this loan, they can enlarge their businesses, support their families and make a better future for their families. They are really happy with this process in this poor country.

loans.use: To enlarge their business

loans.name: Charita

texts.en:
Charita F. is from the village of Danao. She is 45 years old. Charita is married and has 8 adult children. To make a living, Charita owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling baked goods in the local community. Charita has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 1,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Charita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Charita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Charita is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Charita from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Marie Esperance

texts.en: Marie Espérance M. is a 40-year-old widow with four children. For the past 3 years she has run a small clothing store in the capital, Kigali. She is the only one employed at the business and brings in a modest profit of 60,000 Rwandan francs (FRW) per month. This is her first loan request from Vision Finance Company. She will use the 500,000 FRW loan to grow her business.

loans.use: Business growth

loans.name: Felix

texts.en:
Felix M. is from the village of Danao. He is 57 years old. Felix is widowed and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Felix owns and operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Felix has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Felix joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Felix has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase fishing equipment, including hooks and nets. Felix is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Felix from PMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Benedict Okoth

texts.en: Benedict Okoth is married with three children. He runs a butcher shop in Kisumu city, which he started after accessing his first loan from KADET. He sells predominantly beef products and also runs a small café, jointly with his wife. He hopes to use the money from this, his second loan, to re-stock his butcher shop and to diversify into other meat products like chicken. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To improve his butcher business and to sell other meat products like poultry

loans.name: Joselyne

texts.en: Joselyne U. has had a computer-service business for five years in Kigali, the capital of Rwanda. She is 42 years old, married and has three children, aged 7, 9, and 11. Her requested loan of 500,000 Rwandan francs (FRW) will be used to buy a new machine to add to her service.

loans.use: New machine

loans.name: Margaret Auma

texts.en:
Margaret Auma O. is married with five children. She runs a tailoring shop in Kong'ou Market next to Kendubay which is about 200 km from Kisumu City. She manages the business herself and has has been able to create jobs for two other ladies in her dress-making shop.

She learned about KADET through other existing KADET clients. She is now borrowing her third loan from KADET having fully serviced her second loan of Kshs 49,000 (about $635). Margaret plans to use the current loan to increase and diversify her business by acquiring plastic seats for hire.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing materials, and to acquire plastic seats for hire

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: fatou C. est parent beneficiaire dans la zone de camberene.elle est vendeuse detissus depuis plus de dix ans.voulant diversifier les produits de son activite elle sollicite un pret de cent cinquante mille frs afin de pouvoir parallelement accroitre ses benefices et ameliorer ses conditions de vie familiales.
texts.en:
Fatou C. is a client parent in the Camberene area. She has been a seller of cloth for over ten years. Wanting to diversify the products in her business, she is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs in order to grow her profits and at the same time to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Nanda

texts.en:
Nanda K. M. is the proud owner of a furniture factory in Thecho, Nepal, where she and her husband work alongside two other employees. Furniture factories are quite common in Thecho, and many of Nanda’s friends and relatives also work in the furniture industry.

Nanda is applying for a loan of 30,000 NPR so that she can purchase raw materials, such as wood and nails, to continue making furniture at her factory. Nanda’s business receives orders for a number of different wooden products, including window frames, doors, bed frames and drawers. The business has also recently branched out into making wooden ladders, which have been particularly popular.

Nanda and her husband have raised two children; a son who is currently in high school, and a daughter who has just begun studying at a local university. Nanda hopes that by improving her business she will be able to continue to offer her children a good quality education that will allow them to pursue any career they want.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials, including wood and nails

loans.name: Ofori

texts.en:
Ofori A. is 32 years old, and is married with one child who is currently in school. Ofori is an experienced taxi driver and he also runs a grocery store. He has been involved in these businesses for five and seven years respectively.

Due to his good customer service, a lot of people buy items from Ofori's shop. He sells milk, Milo, sugar, soap, toiletries, candy, biscuits and so on. He works as a taxi driver from morning to late afternoon, and opens his grocery shop in the evening when his customers have returned from work. He sells his grocery items from a shed and hopes for the opportunity to acquire his own store.

Ofori wants to use his loan money to buy, for example, more bags of rice and sugar, and cartons of milk and Milo. He hopes to increase his income in order to support his child’s education. He belongs to a community group, called Honesty Group, where members guarantee for one another as a means of collateral.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items

loans.name: Mmh Fouleymatou

texts.fr: MMH FOULEYMATOU T. EST UNE COMMERCANTE CAPITALISANT UNE EXPERIENCE DE 2 ANS DANS LE DOMMERCE DE DETAIL.ELLE ACHETE DES SACS A MAINS, BIJOUX, LINGERIE EN FRANCE, ALLMENGNE AFIN DE LES REVENDRE AU SENEGAL.ELLE DISPODE D'UNE CLIENTELE POU ECOULER SES MARCHANDISES. ELLE SOLLICITE CE PRET CE AUGMENTER SON FONDS DE ROULEMENT.
texts.en:
MMH FOULEYMATOU T. is a merchant capitalizing on two years of experience in retail commerce. She buys handbags, jewelry, and lingerie in France and Germany in order to resell them in Senegal. She has a customer base for moving these goods on the market. She is requesting this loan to augment her working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To augment working capital

loans.name: Evariste

texts.en:
Evariste N. is a 32-year-old married father of three children, aged one, two and four. He and his family live in Kigali, Rwanda. 

Evariste has a paint business that earns him 210,000 Rwandan francs (RWF) per month. He has produced and sold paint for four years and currently employs two other people. He has requested a loan of 500,000 RWF to expand his business, which will in turn allow him to buy more food for his family, as well as save some money.

loans.use: To expand his paint business

loans.name: Sarumi

texts.en: Sarumi is 41 years old and is married with one child. She has a shop where she sells plastics and gift items. Sarumi is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more plastics and gift items to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more plastics and gift items to sell

loans.name: Elizaphan

texts.en: Elizaphan S. is the 46-year-old owner of a hardware shop in Kigali, the Rwandan capital, where he works 12 hours per day. He is married and has three children aged six, eight, and twelve. He has been in the business for ten years and earns just 150,000 Rwandan francs (RWF) per month. His wife also contributes about 20,000 RWF per month to the family’s income by selling food crops. Now Elizaphan has requested his first loan of 500,000 RWF, which he hopes to use to expand his business and start some savings.

loans.use: To expand his business

loans.name: Handsuren

texts.en:
Handsuren S. is a widow and lives in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. She has a grown-up son who lives with his family separately.

Handsuren runs a small cafeteria in the local shopping mall. Since she started her business in 2007, she has done well and has been able to increase the variety of lunch and dinner choices that she offers. Her business capital has tripled in the last two years from 500,000 to 1,500,000 MNT. With more than twenty years of culinary experience under her belt, she has many regular customers. Handsuren says that by ensuring that the quality and taste of the food she serves is high, she hopes to gain more customers in the town. She is requesting a loan to purchase basic food ingredients for her cafeteria.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients

loans.name: Funke

texts.en: Funke is 29 years old and married with two children. She has a shop where she sells beef pepper soup and fish pepper soup. Funke is requesting the loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase more fish and beef. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more beef and fish

loans.name: Tserendoljin

texts.en:
Tserendoljin G. lives with her husband in Arhangai, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Tserendoljin has a small butchery business, which she started in 2006. Her husband drives his truck to herder families from whom he purchases sheep, goats and cattle at discounted prices. They are slaughtered at their butchery shop for individual sale. When meat prices are high, they usually deliver the meat to the wholesale markets in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. From the beginning, the business has been a success; Tserendoljin's business capital has increased from 200,000 MNT to 1,500,000 MNT.

As the biggest public celebration, Naadam, approaches in July, Tserendoljin and her husband plan to bring more livestock to Ulaanbaatar. Tserendoljin is requesting a loan to purchase more livestock to prepare for the Naadam celebration in the capital. In the future, she wants to move to the countryside and become a herder woman with some 500 livestock.

loans.use: To purchase livestock

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr: Mme T. est une commercante capitalisant une experience de 2 ans dans le commerce de produit cosmetique.elle a ouvert une boutique a dakar afin de repondre a la demande.elle achete les produits en cote d'ivoire afin de les revendre au senagal. cependant elle dispode de clients potentiels pour vendre ses produits.
texts.en:
Ms. T. is a merchant capitalizing on 2 years of experience in the commerce of cosmetics. She opened a shop in Dakar to respond to the demand. She buys goods in Cote d’Ivoire in order to resell them in Senegal. However, she has potential customers for selling these goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To augment her working capital

loans.name: Tumenbayar

texts.en:
Tumenbayar T. lives with his wife in the Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. He is 34 and just got married to his wife last year. Tumenbayar drives a micro van between Arhangai province and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been driving the passenger van between the aimag (province) and Ulaanbaatar for the last nine years. He started his business with a purchase of a small van with 1,000,000 MNT ($1 USD = 1,450 MNT) and today he owns two vans valued at 3,500,000 MNT. 

As he is an experienced driver, customers are happy to choose his service for the long trip. In the future, he hopes to purchase a big bus in order to be able to carry more people at once. He requests a loan to purchase new accessories and tires for his micro van.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his vehicle

loans.name: Oumy

texts.fr: oumy G. est parent beneficiaire dans la communaute de camberene.elle gere une boutique de cosmetiques depuis une dizaine d'annees.elle sollicite un pret de cent milles frs pour repondre aux exigences de la clientele face a la floraison des nouveaux produits.son objectif est aussi d'ameliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Oumy G. is a client parent in the community of Camberene. She has been managing a cosmetics shop for 12 years. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 francs to respond to customer demands in face of the boom in new products. Her objective is also to improve her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance A. is a 48-year-old woman who resides at Bawalashie with her husband and five children. Three of her children are currently schooling. She operates a grocery shop and has been doing this for the past 10 years. She sells items like rice, evaporated milk, canned foods and drinks, assorted cooking oils, washing powder, toilet soaps, candies, biscuits, soft drinks, etc., in the local market where she lives. She also sells cooked rice along the road. 

Constance wants to use the money to buy items such as bags of rice, sugar, cartons of milk, tinned tomatoes, etc., to increase her stock and eventually increase her profit margin to support her kids in school.
